platitude

  • n. 陈词滥调，老生常谈

vomit

  • n. 呕吐物，呕吐

entry.title: composition_1
entry.content:
How do you define happiness after coronavirus?

  • I think my definition of happiness seems to have changed after the coronavirus. Before this disaster, I never had a clear definition about happiness, but as the virus broke out, I started to be afraid and even anxious about the health of my family. I guess the happiness of mine at this time is my family staying healthy.
  • It’s a little serious. Actually, in this special time, staying at home and having the longest winter holiday ever is also a kind of happiness. We can stay with our family and no longer need to be squeezed in and out in the canteen for the food we don’t really like.
  • I am so happy to see our government have done such a good job about controlling the virus and I am proud. But I think I would be happier to see the virus not spreading over the world so fiercely. But things are getting worse. In a year with so many disasters, the environment problem is focused again and the future of the world becomes not so optimistic. A peaceful world could also be a happiness.

  • exp. We made a fence out of this wire mesh.
  • v. 相啮合

entangle

  • v. 使纠缠，卷入
  • to cause (something) to get caught
  • exp. Damn! My hair has become entangled into a knot.

swerve

  • v. 转弯，突然改变方向
  • to change direction suddenly especially to avoid hitting someone or something
  • exp. The car swerved to avoid hitting the dog.

tamper

  • v. 篡改，玩弄，贿赂；
  • to change or touch (something) especially in a way that causes damage or harm
  • exp. I had to tamper with my mark, otherwise my parents would have kicked my ass.
  • n. 填塞者，捣棒

sanitary

  • a. 卫生的；清洁的
  • clean; not likely to cause health problems
  • exp. You should wash your hands for sanitary reasons.

petal

  • n. 花瓣
  • a delicate coloured part of a flower. The head of a flower is usually made up of several petals around a central part.
  • exp. The colourful flower petals cover the ground.

phonetic

  • a. 语音的
  • representing each speech sound with a single symbol
  • exp. Phonetic symbols help us to pronounce different words properly.

set in

  • phr. 开始，到来，生效，流行，设置 (戏剧、小说等的) 背景，上涨，插入
  • exp. We’ll have to wait until the drugs set in and she falls asleep.

latent

  • a. 潜在的，隐伏的。不易察觉的
  • existing, but not yet very noticeable, active or well developed
  • exp. The latent talent of a child is enormous.

trauma

  • n. 精神创伤，外伤
  • a very difficult or unpleasant experience that causes someone to have mental or emotional problems usually for a long time
  • exp. Soldiers often suffer from psychological trauma.

indigenous

  • a. 土生土长的，本土的
  • produced, living, or existing naturally in a particular region or environment
  • exp. Indians were the first indigenous people of the United States.

get nowhere

  • phr. (使) 无进展，行不通
  • accomplish nothing
  • exp. I came up with many ideas, but I got nowhere with them.

expedient

  • a. 有利的，方便的；权宜之计的；
  • providing an easy and quick way to solve a problem or do something
  • exp. We found it expedient to just go straight through the complicated maze.

norm

  • n. 规范，标准；准则；模范
  • standards of behaviour that are typical of or accepted within a particular group or society
  • exp. The students should follow the norms of conduct for the school.

archaic

  • a. 已不通用的；陈旧的，过时的，老式的
  • old and no longer used
  • exp. Radios are becoming archaic today.

conspicuous

  • a. 显眼的；显著的；显而易见的
  • easy to see or notice; likely to attract attention
  • exp. The red man is very conspicuous, since everyone else is blue.

entry.title: words_14
entry.content:
百词斩 雅思 2020/03/06

total 20 words

flutter

  • v. 飘动，飘扬；(鸟等) 振翼，排翅而飞；
  • to move lightly and quickly; to make something move in this way
  • exp. The white flag flutters in the wind.
  • n. 激动不安，紧张

single out

  • v. 挑选，选出
  • select from a group
  • exp. He always singles out good apples for sale.

grim

  • a. 严酷的，无情的；令人沮丧的，令人失望的
  • looking or sounding very serious
  • exp. It’s very hard for the patient to accept the grim result.

magnanimous

  • a. 宽宏大量的，大度的
  • having or showing a generous and kind nature
  • exp. He was magnanimous in defeat and praised his opponent’s skill.

mar

  • v. 毁掉，弄糟，玷污
  • to damage or spoil something good
  • exp. The wedding was marred by the terrible weather.

bungalow

  • n. 平房，小屋
  • a house built all on one level, without stairs
  • exp. A bungalow is a house which has only one level, and no stairs.

detest

  • vt. 厌恶，憎恨，痛恨
  • to dislike (someone or something) very strongly
  • exp. The internet bullies bothered the boy because they detest him so much.

take sth. over

  • v. 接管
  • seize and take control without authority and possibly with force; take as one’s right or possession

crooked

  • a. 弯曲的；歪的；不正当的；不正直的
  • not in a straight line; bent or twisted
  • exp. My teeth are so crooked.

trifle

  • n. 蛋糕
  • slightly; something that is not valuable or important; a cold dessert (= a sweet dish) made from cake and fruit with wine and / or jelly poured over it, covered with custard and cream
  • exp. There are two strawberry trifles on the desk.

threshold

  • n. 门槛；开端
  • the floor or ground at the bottom of a doorway, considered as the entrance to a building or room
  • exp. As you step over the threshold, you will change into a new person.

hard and fast

  • phr. (规则等) 严格的，不容改变的
  • (of rules) stringently enforced
  • exp. My country has hard and fast rules and regulations.

versed

  • a. 熟练的，精通的
  • having knowledge about something
  • exp. The student is well versed in all kinds of subjects.

barometer

  • n. 晴雨表；气压表
  • an instrument for measuring air pressure to show when the weather will change
  • exp. The needle on the barometer is indicating sunny weather.

outweigh

  • v. 比···重要；比···有价值
  • to be greater or more important than something
  • exp. There is something that outweighs money, such as love.

abound

  • v. 充满，很多，富于
  • to exist in great numbers or quantities
  • exp. Grapes abound in his farm.

indignant

  • a. 愤慨的，愤愤不平的
  • feeling or showing anger and surprise because you think that you have been treated unfairly
  • exp. He is indignant about the unfair treatment that the dog received.

tacit

  • a. 心照不宣的，静默的
  • expressed or understood without being directly stated
  • exp. They exchanged a tacit glance when passing each other.

fall back on

  • phr. 求助于
  • depend on
  • exp. When I lost my job, I had to fall back on begging for money.

porous

  • a. 可渗透的，多孔的，可穿越的
  • having many small holes that allow water or air to pass through slowly
  • exp. Sponges are porous so they can absorb a lot of water.

entry.title: words_13
entry.content:
百词斩 雅思 2020/03/05

total 17 words

delinquency

  • n. 【法律】少年犯罪，不法行为 (青少年) ，行为不当
  • exp. The delinquency is showing an increasing trend in many countries.

prompt

  • v. 提示；激起；促进，推动；敦促；
  • to encourage somebody to speak by asking them questions or suggesting words that they could say; to make somebody decide to do something; to cause something to happen;
  • exp. My phone prompts me to get out of bed and finish my paper!
  • a. 迅速的，及时的；
  • n. 提示

erratic

  • a. 反复无常的，不稳定的
  • acting, moving, or changing in ways that are not expected or usual : not consistent or regular

contend

  • v. 搏斗；争辩；坚决主张
  • to compete against somebody in order to gain something
  • exp. The two fighters contend for the championship.

metaphor

  • n. 暗喻，隐喻
  • a word or phrase used to describe somebody / something else, in a way that is different from its normal use, in order to show that the two things have the same qualities and to make the description more powerful, for example She has a heart of stone; the use of such words and phrases
  • exp. We use a metaphor in this sentence: “She is a walking dictionary”.

inhabit

  • v. 居住于
  • to live in a particular place
  • exp. Primitive tribes used to inhabit these forests.

culminate

  • v. 使达高潮，使结束
  • to end with a particular result, or at a particular point
  • exp. The marathon culminates in a winner.

to one’s face

  • phr. 当面；坦白地
  • in one’s presence
  • exp. She wanted to say sorry to her face, rather than sending a message.

prospectus

  • n. 章程，内容简介
  • a printed statement that descibes something (such as a new business or investment) and that is sent to people who may want to be involved in it or invest in it
  • exp. Please read this prospectus to see if you want to invest in our company.

annuity

  • n. 年金，养老金，年金保险，年金享受全
  • an insurance policy or an investment that pays someone a fixed amount of money each other
  • exp. The bank pays me a small annuity payment every year.

evoke

  • v. 使人想起；唤起；引起
  • to bring a feeling, a memory or an image into your mind
  • exp. This picture evokes feelings of summer.

convict

  • n. 犯人
  • a person who has been found guilty of a crime and sent to prison
  • v. (经审讯) 证明···有罪，使···知罪

ferry

  • n. 渡船，渡轮；渡口；
  • a boat or ship that carries people, vehicles and goods across a river or across a narrow part of the sea
  • v. 运送；渡运 (人、车或物等)

hand sth. down to sb.

  • v. (作为传统) 传下，传给
  • passed on, as by inheritance
  • exp. I handed my suit down to my son; it’s so big on him!

contemplate

  • v. 沉思；对···周密考虑；注视
  • to think about whether you should do something or how you should do something
  • exp. I contemplate the meaning of life on the toilet.

aviation

  • n. 航空，航空学；飞机制造业
  • the designing, building and flying of aircraft
  • exp. Aviation is one of my biggest interests-I love airplanes.

bitumen

  • n. 沥青
  • any of various naturally occurring impure mixtures of hydrocarbons
  • exp. Highways are covered in bitumen.

entry.title: words_12
entry.content:
百词斩 雅思 2020/03/04

total 10 words

mitigate

  • v. 减轻，缓和
  • to make something less harmful, serious, etc.
  • exp. She takes the pill to mitigate the dizziness.

prevalent

  • a. 普遍的，流行的
  • that exists or is very common at a particular time or in a particular place
  • exp. It’s prevalent to use this kind of mobile telephones in the 90s.

predecessor

  • n. 前辈；(被取代的) 原有事物
  • a person who did a job before somebody else
  • exp. We should learn from and respect our predecessor’s experience.

come over sb.

  • v. (被感觉等) 支配，攥住，拜访
  • to suddenly feel something; to come and visit for a short time
  • exp. They were very happy when their granddaughter came over.

itinerary

  • n. 旅行计划
  • a plan of a journey, including the route and the places that you visit
  • exp. This is our itinerary of the trip to Europe.

pigment

  • n. 天然色素，颜料
  • a natural substance that gives color to animals and plants
  • exp. A pigment is a substance that gives something a particular color.

substantiate

  • v. 证实，使实体化
  • to prove the truth of (something)
  • exp. The shape of the prints substantiated that it was indeed a dog.

goad

  • vt. 刺激；鼓励
  • to urge or force (someone) to do something
  • exp. The boxer goads his opponent to disturb his mind.

hygiene

  • n. 卫生；卫生学；保健学
  • the practice of keeping yourself and your living and working areas clean in order to prevent illness and disease
  • exp. Hands should be washed with soap to improve hygiene.

renowned

  • a. 著名的
  • known and admired by many people for some special quality or achievement
  • exp. The Eiffel tower is renowned for its beauty and simplicity.

entry.title: words_11
entry.content:
百词斩 雅思 2020/03/03

total 15 words

go on about sth.

  • v. 喋喋不休
  • chatter without stop
  • exp. The professor started going on about something again, so I just left.

fraction

  • n. 部分，片段，碎片；分数
  • a small part or amount of something
  • exp. The biggest fraction of the chart is shown in red.

inundate

  • v. 淹没，泛滥
  • to cover (something) with a flood of water
  • exp. The streets are inundated with water.

assert

  • v. 坚持；断言；肯定地说；维护
  • to state clearly and firmly that something is true
  • exp. They both assert their opposing opinions. Who should I believe?

lottery

  • n. 彩票；碰运气的事，难算计的事
  • a way of raising money for a government, charity, etc. by selling tickets that have different numbers on them that people have chosen. Numbers are then chosen by chance and the people who have those numbers on their tickets win prizes
  • exp. He was checking numbers on the TV to see if he would win the lottery.

ruffle

  • vt. 使起波浪，扰乱，激怒；
  • to move or lift (something) so that it is no longer smooth
  • exp. A light breeze ruffled the surface of the water.
  • n. 荷叶边，花边

embark

  • v. 开始，着手，从事；上船或飞机
  • to get onto a ship; to put something onto a ship
  • exp. Columbus embarked on his journey to America in 1492.

quota

  • n. 限额；配额；定额
  • the limited number or amount of people or things that is officially allowed
  • exp. He was told that the quota of liquor is two bottles per person.

soak

  • v. 浸泡，渗透，吸入；
  • to put something in liquid for a time so that it becomes completely wet; to become completely wet in this way
  • exp. The clothes should soak for a while before washing.

phobia

  • n. 恐惧症
  • an extremely strong dislike or fear of someone or something
  • exp. I have a phobia of heights, so my legs keep trembling from fear.

redeem

  • vt. 弥补；赎回
  • to make somebody / something seem less bad
  • exp. To try and redeem the situation of the stolen sheep, he fixed the broken fence.

monarchy

  • n. 君主政体
  • a country that is ruled by a monarch (such as a king or queen)
  • exp. In a monarchy, the country is ruled by a King or a Queen.

cast sb. (sth.) aside

  • v. 抛弃，废除
  • put an end to a state or an activity
  • exp. He decided to cast his cigarettes aside and quit smoking.

do away with

  • phr. 废除，消灭，去掉
  • terminate or take out
  • exp. A number of countries do away with the death penalty.

entry.title: words_10
entry.content:
百词斩 雅思 2020/03/02

total 17 words

frugal

  • a. 节俭的，俭朴的，不昂贵的，廉价的，花钱少的，不充足的
  • careful about spending money or using things when you do not need to : using money or supplies in a very careful way
  • exp. He’s such a frugal person who always mends his old clothes.

maltreat

  • v. 虐待
  • to be very cruel to a person or an animal
  • exp. The man with a belt in his hand maltreated his son.

crevice

  • n. 缺口，裂缝
  • a narrow opening or crack in a hard surface and especially in rock
  • exp. There is a deep crevice in the ground; make sure not to fall in.

lucid

  • a. 明晰的；头脑清楚的
  • able to be seen through with clarity
  • exp. The professor gives a lucid presentation about how to put an elephant in a fridge.

mansion

  • n. 官邸；巨宅；大厦
  • a large impressive house
  • exp. Look at how huge that mansion is!

stoop

  • v. 弯腰，俯身；
  • to walk or stand with your head and shoulders bent forward
  • exp. It is amazing that they could stoop so low.
  • n. 弯腰

inert

  • a. 不动的，惰性的；行动迟钝的
  • (chemistry) without active chemical or other properties (= characteristics); (formal) without power to move or act
  • exp. These are the common inert gases.

bring forward

  • v. 提出；提前
  • to talk about or show (something) so that it can be seen or discussed by others
  • exp. She is always bringing forward new ideas in meetings.

mishap

  • n. 不幸的事，灾祸
  • a small mistake or amount of bad luck
  • exp. The boy suffered a series of mishaps on the way to school.

equitable

  • a. 公正的，公平的
  • fair and reasonable; treating everyone in an equal way
  • exp. The white rabbit proposed an equitable distribution of the carrots.

have one’s hands full

  • phr. 忙得不可开交；手头事情应接不暇
  • keep busy with sth.
  • exp. The mother has her hands full with both her work and her children.

persevere with

  • v. 坚持，不屈不挠
  • be persistent, refuse to stop
  • exp. If you persevere with your exercise, you can get in shape.

melodious

  • a. 音调悦耳的
  • having a pleasing melody
  • exp. The angel’s song is pretty and melodious.

wail

  • vi. 恸哭；悲叹；
  • to make a loud, long cry of sadness or pain
  • exp. The baby began to wail when he woke up and his mom wasn’t there.
  • n. 恸哭；
  • vt. 哀悼

overture

  • n. 主动表示，姿态，前奏曲，序言，事件的开端，提出问题；
  • a piece of music played at the start of an opera, a musical play, etc.
  • exp. The curtain was opened as the orchestra played the overture.
  • vt. 作为一种主动姿态提出，向···提出建议

pamper

  • v. 纵容，过分关怀，精心照料
  • to treat (someone or something) very well : to give (someone or something) a lot of attention and care
  • exp. It’s very common to see the grandparents pamper their grandson.

grudge

  • n. 妒嫉；忿忿不平；
  • a strong feeling of anger toward someone that lasts for a long time
  • exp. The queen held a grudge against Snow White because of her beauty.
  • v. 不情愿做

entry.title: words_9
entry.content:
百词斩 雅思 2020/03/01

total 26 words, 2 similar

become of

  • v. (命运等) 降临，使遭遇，发生···情况
  • to happen to
  • exp. “What has become of my car?!”

oblique

  • a. 斜的，非直角的，隐射的；
  • not direct : not stated directly
  • v. 倾斜
  • exp. The red box is set at an oblique angle to the rest of the boxes.

interrogate

  • v. 审问，审讯
  • to ask someone a lot of questions for a long time in order to get information, sometimes using threats
  • exp. The dog interrogated the kitten to find out the truth about his missing dinner.

palpitate

  • v. (心脏) 悸动，发抖
  • to beat quickly and strongly and often in a way that is not regular because of excitement, nervousness, etc.
  • exp. My heart palpitates when I see the beautiful girl.

plagiarize

  • /‘pleɪdʒəraɪz/
  • v. 剽窃，抄袭 (别人学说、著作)
  • to use the words or ideas of another person as if they were your own words or ideas
  • exp. He plagiarized his essay content from other people’s work.

oblong

  • n. 长方形，椭圆形；
  • having four straight sides that meet at right angles and having two opposite sides that are short and two opposite sides that are long
  • exp. My computer screen is oblong in shape.
  • a. 长方形

lose one’s bearings

  • phr. 迷失方向，不知所措
  • get lost; lose one’s way
  • similar. find one’s bearings
    • v. 指明方向

rehabilitate

  • v. 使康复，使恢复名誉，使恢复原状
  • to bring (someone or something) back to a normal, healthy condition after an illness, injury, drug problem, etc.
  • exp. We will help rehabilitate your legs, until you can walk on your own again.

defiled

  • v. 污损，弄脏；以纵队前进；
  • to make (something) dirty
  • exp. The factory defined the river with sewage and waste.
  • n. 隘路

colossal

  • /kə’lɑːsl/
  • a. 巨大的，庞大的；巨像 (似) 的
  • very large or great
  • exp. That’s one colossal pumpkin.

custodian

  • n. 监护人，保管人，看守人
  • a person who cleans and takes care of a building
  • exp. He is happy to be a custodian of this forest.

bear sth. (sb.) out

  • v. 证实
  • confirm, substantiate
  • exp. He had an idea about the criminal’s identity, and looking at the fingerprints bears his idea out.

put an end to

  • v. 停止，消灭
  • kill an masse; kill on a large scale; kill many
  • exp. The new spray puts an end to ants and other bugs.

get at sb. (sth.)

  • v. 到达，得到
  • to reach effectively
  • exp. I used a ladder to get at the apple.

neurosis

  • n. 【心理】神经症，神经衰弱症
  • an emotional illness in which a person experiences strong feelings of fear or worry
  • exp. Lack her sleep made her neurosis come to the fore.

pungent

  • a. 刺鼻的；刺激性的
  • having a strong taste or smell
  • exp. The onions are very pungent! I’ll have to shut my nose.

maim

  • v. 使残疾
  • injure so badly that part of body is permanently damage
  • exp. The soldier was maimed during the war, suffering the loss of a limb.

mundane

  • a. 单调的；普通的，平凡的
  • not interesting or exciting
  • exp. His life is much more mundane compared to that of his friend.

brashness

  • n. 莽撞，无礼，轻率
  • the trait of being rash and hasty
  • exp. His brashness and drunken antics embarrass both himself and the poor waiter.
    他的无礼和醉酒行为不仅把自己陷入难堪的境地，也让可怜的侍者手足无措。
    • antics
    • n. 滑稽动作；古怪姿态

underwrite

  • v. 给···保险，承诺支付；同意赔款 (海上保险)
  • to give money to support (something, such as a new bussiness) and agree to be responsible for any losses if it fails
  • exp. OK, I’ll underwrite the loan if you promise you can pay.

at the mercy of

  • prep. 在···支配中，任凭···摆布
  • under the control of
  • exp. I’m at the mercy of my boss; he always yells at me.

infest

  • v. 骚扰，寄生于，大批出没
  • to be in or over (a place, an animal, etc.) in large numbers
  • exp. The warehouse is infested with rats.

misgiving

  • n. 疑虑
  • a feeling of doubt about something : a feeling that something might not be right or might not work as planned
  • When I told him the deal, he said he had some misgivings–maybe he didn’t want the deal at all.

vogue

  • n. 时髦，时尚；
  • something (such as a way of dressing or behaving) that is fashionable or popular in a particular time and place
  • exp. Red dresses are really in vogue this year.
  • a. 流行的
  • similar. vague
    • a. 含糊的，模糊的，不明确的，茫然的
    • n. 模糊不定状态

perennial

  • a. 四季不断的；终年的，永久的；
  • a plant that lives for several years or for many years : a perennial plant
  • exp. If a plant can last for three seasons or more, it is perennial.

perturb

  • vt. 使不安；使紊乱
  • to cause (someone) to be worried or upset
  • exp. The coming test perturbs the unprepared student.

entry.title: words_8
entry.content:
百词斩 雅思 2020/02/29

total 29 words

fastidious

  • a. 难讨好的，爱挑剔的
  • being careful that every detail of something is correct
  • exp. Cats are very fastidious cleaners.

morbid

  • a. (精神等) 变态的
  • relating to unpleasant subjects (such as death)
  • exp. Morbid obesity appears to be a standout risk for heart failure.

ostensible

  • a. 表面上的，伪装的
  • seeming or said to be true or real but very possibly not true or real
  • exp. The ostensible reason for the wolf’s arrival is to wish the chick a happy birthday.

come to terms (with sb.)

  • phr. 与···达成协议
  • to reach an agreement
  • exp. We came to terms with each other and decided to work together.

fend

  • v. (靠自己) 照顾，照料
  • to do things without help; to do basic activities by yourself

  • a very steep side of a mountain or cliff

  • exp. Rhetoric is the study of how to use words to convince people.

  • n. 两栖动物。水陆两用飞机和车辆；

  • exp. Frogs are one kind of amphibian.
  • a. 两栖类的，【车辆】水陆两用的，具有双重性格的

  • n. 非法侵入

pollinate

  • vt. 传花粉给···
  • to give (a plant) pollen from another plant of the same kind so that seeds will be produced
  • exp. Bees pollinate many of the flowers in the garden.

traction

  • n. 拽；牵引；牵引力；附着摩擦力
  • the action of pulling something along a surface; the power that is used for doing this; a way of treating a broken bone in your body that involves using special equipment to pull the bone gradually back into its correct place; the force that stops something, for example the wheels of a vehicle, from sliding on the ground; the extent to which an idea, a product, etc. becomes popular or gains support
  • exp. Wheels move forward by traction.

settle (sb.) in

  • phr. 迁入 (新居)，(使) 习惯
  • settle into a position, usually on a surface or ground
  • exp. Shortly after moving into their new house the family seem to have settled in.

find one’s bearings

  • find out the right way
  • exp. I could find my bearings using the app on my phone.

entry.title: translation_1
entry.content:
Origin

  1. The government is launching a massive campaign against corruption.
  2. The year 1939 had witnessed the con:“”quest of Poland by Germany.
  3. We adopted the following strategies: When the enemy advances, we retreat: when they retreat, we pursue.
  4. We tried to engage him in our conversation, but in vain.
  5. Improved consumer confidence is crucial to economic recovery.
  6. The local government developed its economy but at the cost of environment.
  7. I injured my ankle and had to limp.
  8. The professor instructed us that we had one month to conduct the project.
  9. How much longer is the meeting going to drag on?
  10. I got B minus in the final examination.
  11. My family has been engaged in farming for generations.
  12. These people are very efficient, very organized and excellent time managers.

Translation

  1. 政府正在发动一场大规模的反腐运动
  2. 1939年见证了德国对波兰的征服
  3. 我们采取以下战术：敌进我退，敌退我进
  4. 我们试图让他参与到我们的谈话中，但没有成功
  5. 改善消费者信心对经济恢复至关重要
  6. 地方政府以牺牲环境为代价发展经济
  7. 我脚踝受伤了，走路很费劲
  8. 教授给我们一个月的时间进行这个项目
  9. 这场会议还要拖多久？？？
  10. 期末考试我拿了个B-
  11. 我家世世代代从事农业
  12. 这些人做事效率高，有条理并且善于管理时间

“The richest New Yorkers hoard their wealth, starving our communities of revenue for more affordable housing, better public schools, improved infrastructure, new clean energy projects and other public goods and services that would benefit millions of residents,” the groups wrote in their letter.

Origin
The automobile has revolutionized transportation since it was invented, changing forever the way people live, travel and do things. But on the other hand, there are hazards, especially road deaths. Today, however, thanks to computer technology and the application of electronic sensors, it is possible to eliminate most of the traffic accidents that occur. For example, electronic sensors mounted on your car can detect alcohol vapor in the air and refuse to start up the engine. Similarly, sensors can monitor traffic conditions by picking up signals sent out from satellites in orbit and greatly reduce your chances of getting stuck in traffic.

entry.title: DataBase-Notes-1
entry.content:
第一章 绪论

  • 1.1 数据库系统概述
  • 1.2 数据模型
  • 1.3 数据库系统结构
  • 1.4 数据库系统的组成
  • 1.5 小结

1.1 数据库系统概述

1.1.1 四个基本概念

数据(data)

  • 数据(Data)是数据库中存储的基本对象，不仅指数字，也指文字、声音、图形、图像或其组合等

      简而言之，凡是能存在计算机里的、能被计算机操作处理的都被数据库视为数据

  • 数据的形式不能完全表达其内容，数据与其语义（含义）是不可分的

数据库

  • 数据库(Database, DB)通俗地说，是存放数据的仓库，是指长期存储在计算机内、有组织的、可共享的大量数据集和
  • 特征
    • 数据按一定的数据模型组织、描述和储存
    • 可为各种用户共享
    • 冗余度较小
    • 数据独立性较高
    • 易扩展

数据库管理系统

  • 数据库管理系统(Database Management System, DBMS)是位于用户与操作系统之间的一层数据管理软件
  • 用途：科学地组织和存储数据、高效地获取和维护数据

数据库系统

  • 数据库系统(Database System, DBS)是指在计算机系统中引入数据库后的系统，在不引起混淆的情况下常把数据库系统简称为数据库
  • 数据库系统的构成
    • 数据库
    • 数据库管理系统(及其开发工具)
    • 应用系统
    • 数据库管理员和用户

1.1.2 数据管理技术的产生和发展 (了解)

  • 数据管理技术的发展过程
    • 人工管理阶段(40年代中–50年代中)
    • 文件系统阶段(50年代末–60年代中)
    • 数据库系统阶段(60年代末–现在)

1.2 数据模型 (重点)

  • 模型：现实世界事物特征的模拟和抽象

  • 数据模型：现实世界数据特征的抽象，应满足三方面要求

    1. 能比较真实地模拟现实世界
    2. 容易为人所理解
    3. 便于在计算机上实现

  • 在数据库中用数据模型这个工具来抽象、表示和处理现实世界中的数据和信息

1.2.1 两大类数据模型

  • 数据模型分为两类 (两个不同的层次)

entry.title: JavaLearn Notes - 2
entry.content:
基本数据类型

  1. C/C++用的ASCII码(8位)，Java用的Unicode码(16位)
  2. true不是1，false不是0！这是两种不同类型

变量

  1. 变量使用之前必须初始化值！

参数传递

按值传递

  • Java中只有按值传递！！！
  • 对象作为参数传入的是地址，因此内容可以被更改，但仍是按值传递

不定长参数

  • 相当于传了一个数组进来
  • 不定长参数要放在所有参数的最后面

方法重载

  • 方法名称相同，参数列表不同
  • 编译器根据方法签名决定调用哪个方法
  • 注意
    • 有时调用方法会有两个或更多可能的匹配，编译器无法判断哪个更为精确，这称为歧义调用（ambiguous invocation）
    • 被重载的方法必须具有不同的参数列表，不能基于不同修饰符或返回值类型来重载方法

      类

  • public
    • 公共类，可以被其他类所使用
    • declares that the class can be used by an class regardless of its package
    • 无任何限制
    • 一个文件只能有一个public类
  • 无修饰/默认说明
    • a class can be used only by other classes in the same package
    • 仅仅能在同一个包中的其他类引用
  • abstract
    • declares that the class cannot be instantiated
    • 宣布该类不能被实例化
  • final
    • declares that the class cannot be subclassed
    • 宣布该类不能有子类

成员变量的访问权限

  • public
    • 公共访问控制符
    • 被所有类访问
  • 默认访问控制符
    • 被同一包中的其他类访问
  • private
    • 私有访问控制符
    • 被该类自身访问
  • protected
    • 保护访问控制符
    • 该类自身、同一个包中的其他类、其他包中的子类访问
  • private protected
    • 私有保护访问控制符
    • 该类自身、所有子类访问

String类

“+”连接符

  • “+”连接符对于直接相加的字符串常量效率很高，因为在编译期间便确定了它的值，形如”I”+”Love”+”Java”; 在编译期间便被优化成了”ILoveJava”
  • 对于间接相加（包含字符串引用，且编译期间无法确定值的），形如”a” + s1; 效率要比直接相加低

entry.title: JavaLearn Notes - 1
entry.content:
代码解释

  1. public 关键字 公共的类 后面要有一个空格 一个文件中只能有一个public类！
  2. class 关键字 类 后面要有一个空格
  3. Test1 类名称 命名规范 驼峰命名法 首字母大写 单词分隔首字母大写
  4. {} 配对 类体 class body
  5. public 关键字 公共方法
  6. static 静态方法 静态方法可以直接访问 不需要实例化
  7. void 方法的返回值为空
  8. main 主方法 入口方法 程序从这个方法进入 并开始执行
  9. main方法所在类是主类，主类必须跟文件名相同
  10. (String[] args) main方法的参数 类型是字符串数组类型
  11. {} 方法体 method body
  12. System 类型里面的一个类 JDK自带的一个类
  13. out 静态变量
  14. println 方法 out变量里面的一个方法 输出到控制台 ln 换行输出
  15. “Hello Java! Here we meet again!” 字符串参数 输出的内容是它
  • 关于println
    • 会把括号里的内容传换成字符串输出，输出对象会自动调用对象的toString()方法
    • 注意下面两句话输出的区别
  1. ; 表示语句的结尾
  2. 注意区分大小写（大小写敏感）（类名、文件名、关键字等）

eclipse常用快捷键

  • Alt+/ 自动补全
  • Ctrl+/ 注释一行
  • Ctrl+Shift+/ 添加块注释
  • Ctrl+1 修复错误
  • Ctrl+Shift+F 格式化代码
  • Ctrl+Shift+O 自动导入包
  • F11 Ctrl+F11 调试 直接运行
  • F5 F6 F7 F8 调试常用键

标识符的命名规则

  • 标识符只能由字母、数字和下划线和美元符号（$）组成
  • 所有的标识符都应该以字母（A-Z或者a-z），美元符（$）、或者下划线（_）开始
  • 关键字不能用作标识符
  • 标识符是大小写敏感的
  • 合法标识符举例：age、$salary、_value、__1_value
  • 非法标识符举例：123abc、-salary

参考

  • 代码解释
  • eclipse常用快捷键
  • 标识符的命名规则
  • Java变量命名规范
  • 类名大小写敏感

entry.title: words_gathering_1
entry.content:
记录平时遇到的词汇

total some words

unprecedented

  • a. 空前的；无前例的
  • having no precedent; novel
  • exp. …the invention of radio and television, the birth and unprecedented growth of the computer industry, …
  • from ComputerN Networks - Andrew & David Chap1 P1

finalize

  • v. 使结束，使完结，最终确定
  • to complete the last part of a plan, trip, project, etc.
  • exp. Do not finalize the design or standard until multiple prototypes have successfully communicated with each other.

draw on

  • phr. 利用；吸收；戴上；临近
  • exp. This RFC draws heavily on ideas put forth by Clark (1998) and Saltzer et al. (1984).
  • put forth
    • phr. 提出；发表；启航；(植物等) 长出；放出

bank on

  • phr. 指望；依靠；
  • exp. so companies must bank on the fact that the technologies they’re creating today will be what customers are looking for a few years down the road, and that they will beat out products from rivals.

topology

  • n. 地质学；拓扑；拓扑学；布局
  • exp. To achieve its goals, the network layer must know about the topology of the network (i.e., the set of all routers and links) and choose appropriate paths through it, even for large networks.
  • related. topographic
    • a. 地质的；地形学上的
  • related. topography
    • n. 地形学；地形，地貌；局部解剖学；地形图，地势图

freedom of expression

  • phr. 言论自由

intrusion

  • n. 侵入，闯入
  • entrance by force or without permission or welcome
  • exp. The celebrity couple is annoyed by the press intrusion into their affairs.
  • trans. intrude
    • vi. 闯入，侵入
    • vt. 强挤入，把 (自己的思想) 强加于人
    • to become involved with something private in an annoying way
    • exp. The robber intruded into my house with a knife.

aptitude

  • n. 天资；自然倾向；适宜
  • natural ability or skill at doing something
  • exp. He has an excellent aptitude for science.

spectate

  • vt. 出席观看
  • be a spectator in a sports event

industrious

  • a. 勤劳的，勤奋的
  • working hard; busy
  • exp. We should be industrious and hard-working like bees.

whiny

  • a. 烦躁的；爱抱怨的；常发牢骚的
  • habitually complaining

condescending

  • a. 贬低的；有优越感的
  • showing that you believe you are more intelligent or better than other people
  • exp. He has a condescending attitude towards his colleagues.

deprivation

  • n. 剥夺；损失；丧失；免职；匮乏；贫困；
  • the fact of not having something that you need, like enough food, money or a home; the process that causes this
  • exp. The criminal suffered the deprivation of political rights.

hoard

  • v. 贮藏，秘藏
  • to collect and hide a large amount of (something valuable)
  • n. 贮藏物

consensus

  • n. 一致同意，合意
  • an opinion that all members of a group agree with

wail

  • n. 恸哭；哀诉
  • vi. 恸哭；悲叹
  • vt. 哀悼
  • to make a loud, long cry of sadness or pain
  • exp. The baby began to wail when he woke up and his mom wasn’t here.

whimper

  • n. 呜咽；啜泣；怨声
  • a complaint uttered in a plaintive whining way
  • v. 呜咽；啜泣；抽噎地哭；抱怨
  • cry weakly or softly

fiery

  • a. 炽烈的；暴躁的；燃烧般的
  • exp. The fighting, fiery figures are covered in flames.

swagger

  • n. 傲慢的态度，大摇大摆
  • My clothes are cheap, but I wear them with a certain swagger.
    我的衣服很便宜，但是我穿出了逼格。
  • v. 大摇大摆地走，吹牛，傲慢
  • a. 豪华时髦的

contract

  • n. 合同，契约
  • v. 感染（疾病）；招致；订合同；订立（婚约）；缩减
  • to get an illness
  • exp. In California, at least 70 people from one church have contracted the virus.

legislator

  • n. 立法者
  • someone who makes or enacts laws
  • enact
    • v. 颁布；制定法律；扮演
    • to make (a bill or other legislation) officially become part of the law

Christian

  • n. 基督教徒
  • a. 基督教的，基督教徒的

evangelical

  • a. 福音的，热切的
  • n. 福音派信徒
  • exp. Christian evangelicals usually interpret the Bible very literally.

congregation

  • n. 集合在一起的群众
  • exp. The congregation of tourists are following the tour guide into the scenic area.

convalescent

  • a. 恢复期的；渐愈的；调养的
  • of or for or relating to convalescence or convalescents
  • returning to health after illness or debility
  • debility
    • n. 虚弱；衰弱
  • n. 恢复中的病人；康复的人
  • a person who is recovering from illness

at length

  • adv. 最后，终于；详细地

ramp up

  • v. 巩固
  • phr. 提高，斜升，提升
  • bolster or strengthen
  • exp. He is trying to ramp up sales.
    他在努力提升销售额。

inexorable

  • a. 不为所动的，坚决不变的
  • n. 坚定不移的人
  • not able to be stopped or changed
  • exp. My inexorable teacher wouldn’t accept my excuse for the missing homework.

the odds were good

  • phr. 可能性很大
  • The odds were good that I would get the same job after graduate from college.

invoke

  • v. 调用，祈求，恳求，引起
  • to ask for help or protection from (something or someone)

social security

  • phr. 社会保障

at an alarming rate

  • phr. 以惊人的速度

fervent

  • a. 热心的；强烈的；炽热的；热烈的
  • having or showing very strong and sincere feelings about sth

endorse

  • vt. 背书；认可；签署；赞同；在背面签名
  • to say publicly that you support a person, statement or course of action

come with

  • phr. 伴随。。。发生； 从。。。开始；与。。。一起供给
